content:
The hardest test case by far (n = 22) is a validator, so it's easy to get 100% on the tests and then time out on the validator after submitting, it would be good to make a harder test case to match.

My code was too naive with generating partitions by simply checking all permutations of digits 2-9 and finding those that sum to n. I thought of trying a recursive partition function at first, but with a timer it seemed too daunting so I opted for the slower but easier solution and ended up with only 50%.

The other reason I lost marks was because I failed to see the "really good" numbers are just square numbers, I thought they had to be powers of 4 (4, 16, 64, etc), so lost on the validator with n = 9.

Maybe a couple more test cases would be good. One with n = 16 and then one with n = 21. With two extra validators also. These would help guide clashers to realise 'really good' is about square numbers and then the n = 21 would help catch whether their solutions are optimised enough.

I managed to fix my solution to still brute force up to n = 22, but now it's a bit smarter about which digits are really needed based on the constraints (i.e. no need to test for partitions including 5, since n = 25 would be the first to use it). Also, I stopped storing the partitions as a big array and used some tricks to save memory.
https://ato.pxeger.com/run?1=PZHvaoMwFMXZV5_i4oehkt1a94dSVvogIiWttoskUYwyW_VJ9qWM7SH2KnuaXaNdQPCck_y4Ofn4qpr9-Xr9burjw-r37kfDBk5ZbbAudsJ555UG7YgjeDoIQnz2sSoanQZBBJsNJUCrbGoDbpVxKc9wKorUdTJpMpuplngaFhBNUs9StVanJOOIwSODJwYvDFaJ9SX5KRpxmShEJoNYrxDBFuIE1uCFiKjaIJA-Kl52vehB6BEoxtmNp1oaNm9M7UkGbuj6eHjjlRk3w_3aXg_solN4EaWX-niUvN5NNJb3EOdJIGCAAU0ms0Pd9WTmaBplbw-DJdiSYqWZahlNmqDQpqTdNqTqyEOuz9uu5z14fDzewRLDxW4Jw1yot_JH5HJG3kqd2hz1f6O3aM9viU4d-qYXnB_y-hlF098f
Am I missing something?  Test case 4 says 11 is bad, but 11 = 2 + 3 + 6 and 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 = 1, right?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very good for learning

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: pas mal

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think that it's friendly to a learner or a student
I'll have to agree with Kastore, this seems too hard to solve in the limited time of a CoC. I also think you should make the first example a good number.

Juju il y a un truc que j'ai pas capter c'est que
10 = 5 + 5 et 1/5 + 1/5 = 2/5 donc bad
11 is good (2+3+6)

1. Remove ">1" in Input section as it is mentioned in Constraints section.
2. Avoid binary outputs as per contribution guidelines: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines
i.e. There should be more than 2 possible answers (currently only "good" and "bad" are possible).

Try to solve this task. Maybe I don't understand statement.
For example Validator 2.
Why 10 is a good number?

Thanks for the comment. I will try to clarify the statement. 
10=2+4+4 and 1/2+1/4+1/4=1 so we can write 10 as the sum of integers such that the sum of their inverse is equal to 1.
Thank you for your comment. I have modified my submission to take into account your remarks.
Thank you ! I had the usual rouding issue. I changed my code to work on this type of cases but I removed 11 in the test cases.
10=2+4+4 et 1/10=1/2+1/4+1/4, la décomposition peut être avec plus de deux nombres
Yes, you are right I already made the change (Selenae commented the same thing) but it wasn't saved for some reason
When did you make the change, because I got stung by the wrong answer in a live clash just before posting the comment.

Thank you for your quick follow-up. Some further comments:
1. "good", "really good" and "bad" should be formatted as constants instead of variables.
2. The last sentence in the Goal section has to be updated too.
Done !

Formatting syntax includes: <<Bold>> [[Variable]] {{Constant}}.
So you may do {{really good}} instead of using quotation marks, for example.
Thanks for your patience. I will try to care more on the presentation for the next times.
having 3 hard coded answers doesn't feel much better than 2 ngl
At least the chances of randomly getting all answers correct are lower, and it follows the contribution guidelines :shrug:
yeah that's what I said to myself as well :p, but there's definitely space for improvement for some clashes with ternary outputs.
Agreed.

Understood now.
Interesting task. I'm not sure it's CoC. Looks like it's harder. It would be a pity if this really good task not solved during 15 minutes CoC. Maybe it's task for Practice?
But, it's only my opinion and maybe for other codingamers it would be more easier.

Yes, it might be too hard for CoC. I will wait to see if other codingamers share your opinion. If so, I will modify the problem to make it suitable for practice (give the decomposition if it exists) because it can be easily proved that all numbers above 24 are good (really good numbers are only perfect square). 
Thank you for your comment anyway !
